Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Representations and Methods for Verifiable Human-Robot Interactions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robotics promises to transform how people work, learn, communicate, and engage in other activities of daily living. To do so, robots must interact with users following conventions and norms that people expect, so that people readily adopt them into their environments. These conventions and norms, however, are highly complex and nuanced, requiring that designers consider an impractical number of scenarios, constraints, and requirements in the design process. This project will build new computational methods to facilitate this process, enabling designers of future robot systems to more easily explore the design space for human-robot interactions and to verify that their solutions satisfy design goals. These methods will help achieve the promise of robotics by improving their safety, effectiveness, and reliability.

The design of robotic technologies for human interaction poses a complex, multifaceted design problem that requires that resulting designs satisfy several constraints. Systematically exploring the solution space for actions and behaviors that meet user expectations, follow norms of human interaction, and ensure safety of nearby humans requires an appropriate computational framework for the evaluation and proactive exploration of the space of possible human-robot interactions. This project will devise a novel framework for computationally representing human-robot interactions and exploring the solution space for robot behaviors and actions that satisfy defined correctness properties. Specifically, the project will develop a set of prototypical interaction scenarios and correctness properties; specify formal representations for interaction states and properties, using a variety of temporal logics; apply and extend existing verification methods to verify correctness; devise methods to translate verification output to design feedback; and validate and demonstrate the applicability of the developed framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The design of robotics applications poses a complex, multifaceted design problem that requires that products and services to satisfy several design requirements. The actions and behaviors of the robot must be safe for nearby humans. For example, a delivery robot approaching its user to make a delivery must prevent collisions with its user in any way. These behaviors must also meet the expectations of and follow the norms followed by their human users. The delivery robot must, depending on the context of the interaction, manage its proximity to its user appropriately, entering the user?s ?personal? space to make a delivery while staying within a ?social? distance to make an announcement or to offer help. Furthermore, robots must show these behaviors and actions in a reliable, consistent, and predictable fashion. The goal of this project was to develop new technological tools to enable designers to make such design decisions using a set of ?correctness? properties, informed by safety standards, task expectations, and social norms, toward facilitating the design of safer, more intuitive, and more reliable robot actions and behaviors. 

To achieve this goal, the research team borrowed methods from the field of program analysis to develop new algorithms, new software tools, and new interfaces that facilitate the design and programming of complex robotics applications. For example, the RoVer system provided designers with a visual programming interface, enabling them to program complex robot behaviors using a set of predefined templates, which we called ?microinteractions,? and analyzed the resulting behaviors against a set of properties using program analysis algorithms, including task expectations and social norms, in order to provide the designer with feedback on their designs. Another system, called Synth?, asked designers to ?act out? how they expected the robot and the users of the robot to behave, observed the designers? speech and body language, generated the necessary program using program synthesis algorithms, and automatically integrated the program into the robot, allowing designers to instantaneously simulate and test what they acted out on a robot. Finally, the research team developed a new algorithm to adapt and refine the robot?s behaviors to the constraints and expectations of a new environment. Using this method, a social robot was able to obtain feedback from the users in its new environment on its behaviors and modify its program to improve them over time. 

The algorithms, software tools, and knowledge developed in this project as well as the findings from validation studies have significantly advanced the state of the art in robot programming, contributing to the development of real-world applications that can benefit society. The findings from the project have been shared with the public in the form of scientific publications, public lectures, and videos that have been published on the Internet. The algorithms and software tools that have been developed in the project have been shared publicly as open source software to support further development and transfer of the findings to practical applications. The project provided two doctoral students in computer science with opportunities for advanced training and professional development. Several undergraduate students in computer science also engaged in project activities, gaining hands-on research experience and receiving academic mentoring. The project activities and personnel have also contributed to the informing of the public about science and technology through outreach events, including ?open lab? events for K-12 groups and a summer camp for young children.
